name: 歐洲文學概論
description: This course is meant to familiarize students with some of the greatest texts of European literature. By exploring them against their historical background, the students will be able to better understand European culture and civilization, while also developing their analytical skills as well as their ability to successfully synthesize literary and extra-literary information.
goals: Have better understanding of European culture and civilization through European literary
Ability to successfully synthesize European literary and extra-literary information
Familiarize students with some of the greatest texts of European literature.
Understand relation between multi-cultures and literature in European context
syllabus:
Update 2020/2/26: New direction of the course this semester: "Contagion and Literature."  
Update 2020/3/1: New syllabus

1.  Introduction, specific problematics, beginnings
2.  The Oedipus cluster: Sophocles, _Oedipus King_  
3.  Greek tragedy and its echoes: Euripides, _Hyppolitus_; Racine, _Ph__è__dre_
4.  The infectiousness of tropes: Thucydides et al.
5.  No school
6.  The medieval imagination: Petrarch, Boccaccio, Chaucer
7.  At the dawn of the modern: Machiavelli, Montaigne, Shakespeare
8.  Defoe, _A Journal of the Plague Year_
9.  Romanticism and disease: Mary Shelley, _The Last Man_
10.  Alessandro Manzoni, _The Betrothed_
11.  The 19th century 1: Ch. Bronte, Gautier, Maupassant, Edgar Poe, Chekhov
12.  The 19th century 2: Arthur Conan Doyle, Oscar Wilde
13.  Selection of Ibsen plays, Thomas Mann, “Death in Venice”
14.  Thomas Mann, _Magic Mountain_
15.  Camus, _La Peste_; Italo Calvino: _The Cloven Viscount_
16.  Saramago, _Blindness_
17.  Independent work I
18.  Independent work II
